title: How much did high school grades affect the rest of your life? - Quora

response.answer_text: Zero effect. Same for my college grades and my grad school grades. That doesn’t mean yours won’t have impact. Not suggesting you should not put forth considerable effort. But grades count in school and for school. If you need a high quality degree from a name school…but do you? If you are going for a job in academia or research, maybe so. But if you plan on getting a job once you have one job under your belt it’s all based on what you’ve done there. You get hired based on what you can do. Grades are utterly irrelevant, in over forty years I cannot once recall being asked about my grades, and not one time did I ever ask any potential employee about theirs. If you did poorly, then get into whatever school you can, and focus on doing well. One year of good grades and you can try applying to transfer to a school you’d rather be in. Unless you were going to be all A’s all the time, and that’s ok but it’s grind and not all fun, there will always be someone with better grades anyway, and competitively you won’t be chosen for that. So be chosen because you’ve lived an interesting life, done interesting things, or just learned to work hard and do the academic thing. There are lots and lots of second chances here. But if poor high school grades have ruined your life I suggest you look up “life” and see what it means. Your life isn’t ruined by your HS grades, and even if it’s affected by them, you might instead think on how you have DIFFERENT opportunities and how you have learned from your mistakes. There’s a heck of a lot of life after high school, and I’m telling you this as a 70 year old man who graduated more than fifty years ago. Now I just hope I don’t screw up my dotage….

My high school grades definitely permanently changed the trajectory of my life. My favorite music schools rejected me or accepted me with poor scholarship offers and I couldn’t afford to attend, so I went to CU Denver instead. I hated the music program there for a lot of reasons, and I continued to do badly because I had no idea how to study, so I switched into English and continued at UCD. I could’ve transferred somewhere else, but my grades weren’t good enough until late in the game, and by that point I figured it was easier to complete the English degree I had an overwhelmingly positive experience in the English department there so I figured I’d keep the party going. But, this would've been avoided had I done better in high school. So, no one cares what I did in HS. I can’t put any of that on my CV and be taken seriously. But the grades did have an enormous impact on the rest of my life because UCD was life-changing for all sorts of reasons, which are far too personal and off-topic for me to share. I’m not restricted from doing what I want now, though, because there is a life outside of schools and I’m blessed with amazing friends who helped me along the way, for friends offer a wealth that an education can’t provide on its own.

They really screwed up my automated AMCAS application for medical school admissions. I did dual enrollment from very young, and my transcripts showed that I went to college before I went to high school. There were some very awkward interviews and some not very nice things a few of the interviewers said to me when it came up. Let's just say some medical schools don't like driven, smart people very much... PhD programs seem to be a lot more interested in enrolling profoundly gifted individuals who have a non-traditional education.

it is, of course, quite impossible to say with certainty. but i failed many high school classes and my grades in others were indifferent. yet i now have degrees in both law and medicine; have partnered with a world-reonowned physician and practiced at an ivy league medical center; and worked as a molecular biology fellow under a nobel-prize short lister at a world renowned private research facility. so, at the very least, one can say that my professional and academic possibilities were not materially foreclosed by desultory results in high school.

If they prevent you from getting into college* which is somethig you wanted, yes, they would. Otherwise, they don't amount to a hill of beans. No one cares, no one asks, no one wants to know. (Your high school aged children will want to know, but they will be the only ones.) Having or not having a diploma will matter in the job market, but otherwise, to be honest, the letters on a transcript don't matter. The acquisition or lack of knowledge indicated by the grades might matter, but not the grades themselves. *With community colleges available to anyone over eighteen, you can get into college even without a high school diploma. The admission office doesn't even care about your grades. After two years of success at a community college, you can go to most any four-year you can afford. With apologies to all the high school teachers, but what you teach is important, the grades on a transcript, not so much.

College admissions, either right out of high school or many years later, at some level high school grades are factored into the equation for admission to some institutions up until you earn at least a BA/BS. Will it prevent you from achieving your dream job to have low high school grades? Depends on what the dream is. If it involves something where “where you went” is as important as other parameters of your resume, then they could. Alma mater in fields such as Wall Street/Banking is much more about your MBA or graduate degree, but your entrance into those grad programs can be influenced by where you earned your BA/BS, so ultimately, it can have an impact. Bottom line, even if you think you’d never want to go to college, or never be interested in something that might require a marquee name on a piece of parchment, working to your best ability in high school has rarely been a detriment for anyone.

Grades affect your life like salt in your favourate dish i.e. very little. Like salt put in right amount can improve the taste to the next level ,same is the case with grades. But when you do not have salt , it depends on your creative mind to search an alternative to it. Sometimes it makes it even better and makes it poor as hell. So pickup the right alternative incase you do not have the salt and there are times when even having salt does not help because the dish was itself bad.

High school grades can be an important factor to getting accepted into college. After that, they are totally unimportant. If your high school grades aren’t so good, then attend a community college for a year or two. Success in community college can also get you into a four-year college.

High school grades were an indication of what I liked, and what I was good at. They enabled me to go to college, and choose a major where I could be successful. In college, grades enabled me to get scholarships which helped me get through with less stress. You should use high school to learn about yourself as well as the curriculum. Don’t waste the chance.

I think the most important thing that can affect your life is your motivation, not high school grade. A lot of teenagers at that moment are in temperature feelings, so they have to be able find someone or tutor that can motivate them and find yourself passion, kid.

My high school grades per se have influenced my life minimally. What I learned in high school has been pivotal. What I learned academically and socially in the classroom, physically in the gymnasium and sports field, and emotionally in the jobs I held outside school laid the foundation for the rest of my life.
only that they were good enough for me to go to a decent university :-) Northwestern…..
Yes. Your grades affect your college, your college affects your career, and your career affects your retirement. The Butterfly Effect of HS grades.
